newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania's Renel seeks more fuel imports, loan.
newsitem.headline: Romania's Renel seeks more fuel imports, loan.

text.p: Romania's state electricity utility Renel RA has imported 1.15 million tonnes of fuel oil since January and plans further imports financed by a syndicated loan, a spokesman for the utility said on Wednesday.
"Our plan is to optimise fuel imports, namely to buy large quantities at the smallest possible price on the spot market," spokesman Eugeniu Ene told Reuters.
Since January 1, Renel imported 1.15 million tonnes of fuel oil, he said. But he declined to give figures on Renel's future import deals.
"We will import only fuel oil as the price of imported gas is some 300 percent higher," he said. "However, the monthly average will be lower than that recorded during the past winter months."
Ene cited Vitol, Glencore, Trafigura and Galaxy among the foreign trade firms involved in import operations.
"We worked out an arrangement with Glencore to pay for the fuel after delivery," Ene said, adding that Renel had bought 300,000 tonnes of fuel from Glencore oil since October.
Renel has to import large quantities of fuel to produce power for an oversized industrial sector.

Ene said the company was negotiating a syndicated loan with seven Western banks, including Chase Manhattan Corp, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd, Bank of America, Citibank, ING Bank, Northwest Bank and Deutsche Morgan. But he said it too early to discuss specific figures.
In February, Renel raised $150 million through a corporate bond issue launched through Merrill Lynch International, to finance part of its gas and fuel oil imports and upgrade power plants.
Last December, Renel signed a $160 million syndicated loan, the first corporate raising by a Romanian company on the international markets, also for fuel imports. The loan was arranged by ING Bank.
